Computer Networks & Distributed Systems (CN&DS)
—

Leslie Lamport: ,,A distributed system is one in which thefailure ofa computer you
didn't even know existed can render your own computer unusable.”

What is a ”distributed system" (D5)?

0 Preliminary (!) answer: A system where computers cooperate “closely"
— Cooperation yields one system (-of-systems) to a certain extent
7 This extent i.e. the service/functionaiity of the one system can be specified somehow

— WOU no eXiS Wit 0U

. In other words: no distributed system without computer network
0 So, we look at systems where:
7 There are several computers (of kinds)
7 The computers are connected by a computer network (CN)
7 ...most interesting problems stem from the network & the distributed nature
0 There are various kinds of such systems — where does CN end and DS begin?
7 Internet, IPTV, P2P, VolP telephony,

Motivation
—

- Focus of this course:
Basic building blocks for networked applications

- Networking is a fast-moving area
7 Basic, fundamental knowledge becomes important

0 Three parts in the course

    
 

ations of networking

- How the theory is applied in practice

W

- So that the course isn’t too boring“. ;-)

- Fu ndamental theory:

y~

N
— Internetworking: How to connect physical networks and address devices
— Routing (extension to GT): How do we find the way for messages to get from A to B.
— Multicest: How can we send a message to a group of recipients?
7 Transport: How do we build reliable connections?

- Distributed Systems and Applications:
— Web protocois (HTTP)
7 TLS

— Name resolution (DNS)

Basic Example 2: Telephony

- What happens when picking up a telephone and making a phone call?
— How to find the peer's phone? How to transmit speech?

 

- What are the crucial differences between transferring a Web page and a phone call?
— Web: Bunch of data that has to be transmitted
— Phone: Continuous flow of information, must arrive in time

. By the way: what actually is ”data” & ”information”?

Simplest Communication: Direct Physical Connection

 

- Web example: Browser=client and server
— Simplest case: direct‘y connect them by a (pair of) cable

.
Server

7 Server provides data, dient consumes it

 

- Telephony: Connect two telephones via a (pair of) cable

   

10

What Good is a Physical Connection? — Signals

- Information has to be represented as Data has to be
represented by signals

0 Signal: Representation of data by characteristic changes (in
time or space) of physical variables

- Material example: Letters on paper
- Immaterial example:

— Acoustic waves when speaking

— Current or voltage in a wire

Bits and Signals

 

. What should be communicated: Data, represented as bits
0 What can be communicated between remote entities: Signals

0 Needed: a means to transform bits into signals
7 And: from signals back into bits at the receiver

m‘ Lectures

 

CNuVS (Computer Networks & Distributed Systems): "canonical", mandatory (D, SS, IVS)
I Usually: Prof. Miihlhéiuser; at times: Prof. Steinmetz (e.g., SS 17)
I Basics: Internet protocols and mechanisms, some distributed algorithms, queuing theory.

TK1: Distributed Systems and Algorithms (E, WS, 2+2)
I together with TK3, considered one of two pillars ofTK lectures

TK3: Ubiquitous Computing (E, 55, 2+2)
I Ubiquitous Computing (anytime-anywhere, networked embedded&worn computers)
I includes: Mobile Communications. Mobile lnternet, Mobile Computing

TK2: Human Computer interaction (55, 2+0/2)
I Everything you need for building good User Interfaces

Ubiquitous Computing in Business Processes (D, W5, 2+0) [Heusen Nochta]
I "Applications of TK3 within SAP 81 co. 9 within Smart Cities”

Further related lectures @CS dept.: Proffs. Hollick, Suri, plus: Distributed SW Engineering
Lectures offered by etit department (F318), Profs Steinmetz, plus in part: Klein

m‘ Seminars, Labs (Praktikum),

 

Project practicum TK (P6, 9CP)
I Groups of 3—5 work on a subject 9 software, prototypes

I Samples of typical topics:
I ubicomp: smart kitchen, smart products
I future HCI: interactive table, augmented everyday objects,
I ,big data' in sensor networks: visualization, simulation,
I novel programming paradigms : subject oriented workflows, pseudocode lge.,
I security&trust: eCash based reputation systems, author recognition in documents,

IOne topic left: Blockchain / Hyperledger related
I If interested, contact alexopoulos@tk.informatik.tu-darmstadt.de

 

Research Project (Forschungsprojekt) TK (12CP):
I Research—related open topics, Only MSc students!
I Conduct research and write a paper
